climbs.name: Winter Wine
climbs.fa: Jonny Woodward and Randy Vogel - Nov 1982

content.description: Start as for Gem, but move right along the quartz dike for 12' and past a 3' THIN crack (RP's here).  Continue another 8' of awkward face climbing with no pro to join a splitter hand crack.  Descend as for Gem.
content.protection: I toproped this one using a few cams (.5, .75, 3?).  If leading, be sure to include RPs to protect a short thin crack section.

content.description: This poorly-protected and seldom done route begins just left of a large block leaning against the face (see photo) and climbs the path of least resistance into the crack which starts about 30' up. Falling is not an option at the start if leading this, but once in the crack enjoyable jamming leads to the top.
content.location: This is the crack right of Colorado Crack which begins partway up the face.

climbs.name: Tapeworm Traverse
climbs.fa: George Armstrong, a guy named Hugh, Todd Gordon, 9-1993

content.description: Climb a crack about thirty feet right of "GEM", then traverse right along a dike and follow a thin crack to the top.
content.protection: Draws and some thin to medium crack gear.

content.description:
Start as for Tapeworm traverse, but continue straight up.

I don't know the FA or other beta for this climb so comments are appreciated.
content.location: This is the crack to the right of GEM.

climbs.name: Spiderman
climbs.fa: John Long and John Bachar, September 1975

content.description:
This is a burly 10a in my opinion.  My climbing partner kept repeating "There is no way this is 10a" all the way up while following.  On first glance, it appears that the route is essentially over once you pull through the overhanging section 25' off the ground.  To my surprise, I found the rest of the route to be pretty sustained all-in-all.

Begin just left of Colorado Crack.  An overhanging section lies 25' off the deck.  Above here, the flared crack is somewhat difficult to protect.  The last 15' or so before topping out is wide and awkward.

Anchor: slung block.

To descend, scramble off to the north (climber's right) as for Colorado Crack.  This involves a move or two of downclimbing.
Unless you climb way harder than the grade don't lead this.  Single bolt is old and homemade.  Crack is wide and flaring.  Climb is R rated but could be considered X to....
content.location: 30ft to the right of Fool's Gold

content.description: A beautiful 5.9 hand crack that is a good way to fill the time if you're waiting in line for "Gem" or "Colorado Crack." Crux for me was the wide section at the beginning and there is an awesome rest about 2/3rds the way up. After the rest the steepness eases and the crack widens.
content.protection: 1X.75 and doubles from #1-#3, You could place larger cams up higher after the rest if you wanted but its easy terrain. Bring a long sling to wrap around the boulder at the top for an anchor.
content.location: The route is located on the north side of Conan's Corridor. To approach walk to the routes like "Colorado Crack" and go north. Scramble down and to the left until the ground flattens out. The crack will become visible as you approach it. It is the route directly to the left of Pictures at an Exhibition. To descend, just walk west.

climbs.name: Pictures at an Exhibition
climbs.fa: Michael Paul, Scott Gordon, Reggie Thomson, Mike Brown, Mark Haveman, Todd Gordon & Ian Carter, December 1978

content.description: This climb lies on the west side of the rock with Colorado Crack. Walk past the right end of the wall, turn left and after a short distance a wall with a distinctive dike will be seen. A short but fun climb that is a nice diversion from the cracks at Conan's Corridor, especially if that area is crowded.

Boulder up the grainy apron to a shallow flared horizontal. Above the horizontal follow the thin discontinuous right trending orange dike and two smaller discontinuous parallel dikes. Utilizing the dikes to friction and palm, diagonal up and right up the grainy face past three bolts. Belay at a large hollow sounding flake with medium to large cams.
content.protection: 3 bolts, several cams 2 - 3" for the anchor.
content.location:
Not in Conan's Corridor, but on the west face of the same formation. Located on a triangular face 60 feet right of

Pictures at an Exhibition

. There is a large and active bee hive in a large hueco/chimney-like feature 20 feet right of the base. Descend by down climbing the slab and blocks left of the route.

content.description: A short and relatively sandy offwidth just to the left of right crack.. hence the name "left crack".. get it? Crux is getting into the crack itself, once you have your body positioned right you can inch your way up the crack. 2/3rds the way up the crack becomes fist and bulges over.
content.protection: Large cams and a number 3-3.5 for the top. Sling the boulder above right crack for an anchor.
content.location: On the north side of Conan's corridor, just to the left of right crack. Cant miss it.. See right crack for more Info.

content.description: Climb Spiderman about 6 feet above the first horizontal.  Do not go left at the old bolt at the horizontal.  Go left at the first faceholds, then up various rounded holds, roughly 3-6 feet left of Spiderman.  This route has really fun movement.
content.protection: Use same gear anchor as Spiderman.

climbs.name: Gem
climbs.fa: John Bald, Hugh Burton, and John Long - January 1974

content.description: Gem is a shorter crack (just 60') on the right hand side of the Corridor Face to the right of Colorado Crack.  Climb the hand crack which widens to fists towards the top.  Anchor: slung block (cordalette and/or long webbing helpful).  To descend, scramble off to the north (climber's right).  This involves a move or two of downclimbing.

Fool's Gold is the first (leftmost) route on the Corridor Face proper.  It follows a prominent trough past a single bolt into and into a double crack system.

The cruxes are down low, at ten and twenty feet.  The first is pretty much unprotected, but with a reasonably clean fall if you're well spotted.  The second is slightly above your first gear.

The double cracks don't take gear the way you might hope, so don't pass up all of the pockets on your way up the trough.

All in all, a committing, relatively sustained, fun route at its grade.
content.protection:
Standard rack through #3 Camalot.

Pro is adequate, but not abundant.  Passing up any of the good placements will probably set you up for a groundfall.

climbs.name: Colorado Crack
climbs.fa: Billy Westbay, John Long, and Hugh Burton - Sept 1975

content.description:
Colorado Crack is THE climb to do in the greater Jumbo Rocks area.

This 100' crack lies in the middle of the Corridor Face just right of

Spiderman

and is right-angling at the bottom, then vertical to the top. Face climb past large huecos to the right-angling hand crack. Continue up a vertical finger crack with nice face holds on exquisite rock.

Anchor: natural gear.

To descend, scramble off to the north (climber's right).  This involves a move or two of downclimbing or...take DE's advice: "bring a skateboard for the descent, you might have to ollie the six inch bump encountered halfway down".
content.protection: Medium to large nuts, a double set of cams .5 to 2", plus one 3" piece; skateboard optional.

climbs.name: Boulderado (aka California Face)
climbs.fa: (TR) Al Swanson, 2003, First Lead: Bob Gaines & Frank Bentwood, April 2009

content.description: This is the face to a right-slanting offset seam between Colorado Crack and True Dice. 3 out of 5 stars.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a 2-bolt lower-off anchor. 100 feet

content.description:
This variation on True Dice allows for a safer beginning.  Start up Boulderado for the first three bolts, slinging them all long, with a double runner on the third.  Move right on large buckets to the base of the crack and continue up the rest of True Dice.

There is gear at selected intervals, and a tough to protect section just before the top.
